alert.note: Alert for Kankakee (Illinois) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Chicago (Northeastern Illinois and Northwestern Indiana)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued January 27 at 10:30AM CST until January 29 at 12:00PM CST by NWS Chicago
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Illinois and Indiana... Iroquois River at Iroquois affecting Iroquois and Newton Counties. Sugar Creek at Milford affecting Iroquois County. Kankakee River at Momence affecting Kankakee County. Vermilion River near Leonore affecting La Salle County. Kankakee River at Shelby affecting Newton and Lake (IN) Counties. ...FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL EARLY MONDAY AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Flooding caused by a combination of snowmelt and heavy river ice. * WHERE...Kankakee River from the IL/IN state line downstream to the confluence with the Iroquois River at Aroma Park, including the Momence gauge. * WHEN...Until early Monday afternoon. * IMPACTS...At 4.0 feet, water overtops low-lying banks at River Isle upstream from Momence. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 9:00 AM CST Saturday, the river stage was 4.4 feet. Kankakee County Emergency Management indicated shifting ice and multiple ice jams occurring along the Kankakee River from Kankakee upstream to near Sun River Terrace. Heavy river ice was observed farther upstream along the river. - Forecast...Shifting and breaking of river ice may cause new ice jams and flooding. Ice jams upstream of the area are breaking up, which could cause additional ice to accumulate in the area. - Flood stage is 5.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: River rises are being affected by significant river ice cover and by snowmelt. Significant river ice cover can lead to ice jams that cause large water level fluctuations and flooding with little advanced notice. A Flood Warning means that water levels above flood stage are imminent or may already be occurring. Persons along rivers and streams in the warned area should take immediate precautions to protect life and property. Report flooding to the National Weather Service or your local law enforcement agency only when you can do so safely. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued by late tonight at 430 AM CST.
